MR. BURKE: Why do you think the United States government held so many Japanese-Americans in internment camps during World War II?

MAGGIE: Well, it was national security. It’s important to be safe.

JOE: I don’t think so. It was just prejudice. They weren’t confined for any other reason than their race. That’s racist.

PAUL: It’s racial profiling, just like a DWB—you know, driving while black. The police stop you just because you’re black, because they think you’re more likely to have drugs or guns. It’s the same thing.

MAGGIE: Well, the truth is that young black men are more likely to have drugs or guns, and the Japanese did bomb Pearl Harbor. Those Japanese-Americans were more likely to have sympathy with their own country. After all, there wasn’t another Japanese surprise attack, was there? It must have worked.
